message_1: Suppose Alice wants to send a confidential message to Bob using the Diffie-Hellman key exchange algorithm. Alice uses a prime number p = 23 and a primitive root g = 5 as public parameters. Alice chooses a secret integer a = 6 and computes the value A = g^a mod p. Similarly, Bob chooses a secret integer b = 15 and computes the value B = g^b mod p. Calculate the shared secret key that Alice and Bob can use to encrypt and decrypt their message.
message_2:
First, let's compute the values of A and B.

A = g^a mod p
A = 5^6 mod 23
A = 15625 mod 23
A = 8

B = g^b mod p
B = 5^15 mod 23
B = 30517578125 mod 23
B = 19

Now, Alice and Bob can compute the shared secret key using the following formulas:

Shared Secret Key (Alice) = B^a mod p
Shared Secret Key (Alice) = 19^6 mod 23
Shared Secret Key (Alice) = 47045881 mod 23
Shared Secret Key (Alice) = 2

Shared Secret Key (Bob) = A^b mod p
Shared Secret Key (Bob) = 8^15 mod 23
Shared Secret Key (Bob) = 35184372088832 mod 23
Shared Secret Key (Bob) = 2

The shared secret key that Alice and Bob can use to encrypt and decrypt their message is 2.
